text: Mineral matter (ions) dissolves where grains are in contact with each other (areas of high stress) and is deposited in pore spaces (areas of low stress).

The shape of a mineral may also be altered by a process in which individual atoms move from a location along the margin of the grain that is highly stressed to a less-stressed position on the same grain .
As a result, the mineral grains tend to become shortened in the direction of maximum stress and elongated in the direction of minimum stress.

Flattened rock containing elongated quartz grains of a mineral’s crystalline structure slide relative to one another along discrete planes, thereby distorting the grain, as shown in This type of gradual solidstate flow involves slippage that disrupts the crystal lattice as atoms shift positions by breaking existing chemical bonds and forming new ones.
This mechanism, called pressure solution, is significantly aided by hot, ion-rich water.
While both of these mechanisms flatten mineral grains, the mineralogy remains the same.
